title: Change Minds Or Drive Turnout?
summary:
Key ideas
- Democrats believe that moving towards the center will make them electable.
- Halls & Thompson (2017) found that the more extreme a candidate, the lower their party’s share of total turnout.
- Hall and Thomspon also concluded that effects on turnout might be the entire reason why extremist candidates do worse.
- There is little data on vote-switching, but CNN's exit poll from 2008 suggests that 17% of people who voted Republican in 2004 went Democrat in 2008.
- Nate Cohn of the New York Times found that white working-class Obama supporters switched to Trump, and that shifts in turnout were not the dominant factor in Trump’s success among white working-class voters.

Key learnings
- Extreme candidates tend to do worse in elections.
- Base voter turnout is important, but swing voters can make a big difference in close elections.
- Moving towards the center may not be the best tactic for the Democrats to win elections.

Key questions
- Do more extreme views increase base turnout?
- Is base turnout really the only thing that matters?
- How do swing voters compare to base turnout as a determining factor in elections?
- Can a candidate appeal to the base and swing voters at the same time without compromising their principles?
